resources.string: Please enter the OTP sent to your registered email address
Your password has been successfully changed
Everything you need to monitor your pathway to responsive sleep
Pay once and get access to the complete guide.
Enter referral/discount code to get discount.
Yippee!! You have got a discount of 25% with your discount code.
It’s also important you follow the current NHS Cot Death & SIDS guidelines at all times
Select your little one to start your Pathway to responsive sleep session.

The method for under 6 months is designed around a “cuddle, calm, continue“. There is an initial 10-minute wait while you give them a chance to self-settle. You then listen and respond depending on the level of crying, which is described in the crying scale. read more

The method used for 6 months and over is based around "respond, reassure & resume”. There is an initial 10-minute wait while you give them a chance to self-settle. You then listen and respond depending on the level of crying, which is described in the crying scale. read more

string-array.name: a
string-array.item: Put baby down after their regular bedtime routine, as awake as you can, say goodnight reassuringly and leave the room.

They may start to cry immediately. Whatever happens, you leave them for 10 minutes. This stage is giving your baby a chance to settle themselves and many babies can settle within that first 10 minutes. Your baby may or may not.

You should go in if your baby is sick which does occasionally happen. In this case change your little one and the bedding, cuddle and calm them before putting back down. Come out and continue the process
Once the first 10 minutes has passed…listen: Now follow the crying scale suggestions.1

If your little one is crying consistently at 4 or above on the crying scale. Go into them calmly, but don’t pick them up, reassure them , you can stroke them , talk to them gently , then leave. They may still be crying or start immediately but still leave, you have reassured them you are still there.

Listen again. Wait for a minute or two as they may be really cross so wait and …. Repeat You may need to go in frequently every 2-3 minutes or it may be 15-20 minutes. Listen and respond. If you find that going in makes your baby cry more, climbing the crying scale quicker then don’t go in so often. If it helps, though, then repeat frequently.
Continue this listen & responded until they have gone to sleep.

If they wake in the night, follow the method again, always leaving that initial 10 minutes of self-settling, before using the crying scale to decide whether to respond and reassure , until they have gone back to sleep.
It is quite normal on the first evening for this process to take a minimum of 45 minutes, with visits in and out when needed, but it can take longer.
Stay strong this will get easier for you and for them each time

string-array.name: b
string-array.item: Put baby down after their regular bedtime routine, as awake as you can, say goodnight reassuringly and leave the room.

They may start to cry immediately. Whatever happens, you leave them for 10 minutes. This stage is giving your baby a chance to settle themselves and many babies can settle within that first 10 minutes. Your baby may or may not.

You should go in if your baby is sick which does occasionally happen. In this case change your little one and the bedding, cuddle and calm them before putting back down. Come out and continue the process

If your little one is crying consistently at 4 or above on the crying scale. Go into them calmly, but don’t pick them up, reassure them , you can stroke them , talk to them gently , then leave. They may still be crying or start immediately but still leave, you have reassured them you are still there.

Listen again. Wait for a minute or two as they may be really cross so wait and …. Repeat You may need to go in frequently every 2-3 minutes or it may be 15-20 minutes. Listen and respond. If you find that going in makes your baby cry more, climbing the crying scale quicker then don’t go in so often. If it helps, though, then repeat frequently.
Continue this listen & responded until they have gone to sleep.

If they wake in the night, follow the method again, always leaving that initial 10 minutes of self-settling, before using the crying scale to decide whether to respond and reassure , until they have gone back to sleep.
It is quite normal on the first evening for this process to take a minimum of 45 minutes, with visits in and out when needed, but it can take longer.
Stay strong this will get easier for you and for them each time

string-array.item: Put baby down after their regular bedtime routine, as awake as you can, say goodnight reassuringly and leave the room.

They may start to cry immediately. Whatever happens, you leave them for 10 minutes. This stage is giving your baby a chance to settle themselves and many babies can settle within that first 10 minutes. Your baby may or may not.

You should go in if your baby is sick which does occasionally happen. In this case change your little one and the bedding, cuddle and calm them before putting back down. Come out and continue the process
Once the first 10 minutes has passed…listen: Now follow the crying scale suggestions.1

If your little one is crying consistently at 4 or above on the crying scale. Go into them calmly, but don’t pick them up, reassure them , you can stroke them , talk to them gently , then leave. They may still be crying or start immediately but still leave, you have reassured them you are still there.

Listen again. Wait for a minute or two as they may be really cross so wait and …. Repeat You may need to go in frequently every 2-3 minutes or it may be 15-20 minutes. Listen and respond. If you find that going in makes your baby cry more, climbing the crying scale quicker then don’t go in so often. If it helps, though, then repeat frequently.

resources.string: The self-settling time is now over. Please select your little one’s crying level right now by choosing the relevant emoji below.
Stop…listen….What is my baby telling me?

Increasing now in volume and frequency. Spikes of shouting but still some pauses from crying. If using a baby monitor with a green to red colour light, it is in the green with occasional spikes in the red.
The cry has turned angry now and is louder with longer spikes in the red on the monitor.
A loud, cross and demanding cry with little or no breaks, on the monitor. It’s in the red and staying there.
The top of the scale with constant high level crying.
Leave your little one, they are fine and super cross that they are not getting their normal cuddle, feed, etc. Remember they are tired and okay. Give the method time and respond when needed
As your little one’s cry is at level 3, we suggest you
The inner timer is the initial 10 minute self settling period
Learning to self settle and sleep independently is a great life skill
The graph shows you how well your little one is doing at self settling, session by session.
